#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Boston/East Boston
#Text=A lot of neighborhoods claim to be diverse , but East Boston is the real deal .
#Text=" Eastie " , as the locals call it , has always been a welcoming place for immigrants hoping to gain a toehold in Boston .
#Text=Rapid gentrification along the waterfront has begun to take hold , and it remains to be seen what impacts that will have on this working class community .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Like much of the rest of the Boston area , East Boston was originally a series of five islands and marshy tidal bogs .
#Text=Each of the islands were used either for farming or the grazing of livestock , and military fortifications were constructed when necessary .
#Text=The two largest islands ( Noddle 's and Breed 's ) make up the modern commercial and residential heart of Eastie .
#Text=The three smaller ( Governors , Apple , and Bird ) were combined with infill over the years to create Logan International Airport .
#Text=In the 1830s , the owner of the largest island , William Sumner , formed a company to direct expansion in the area .
#Text=The railroad was brought in and ferries started service to try and connect East Boston to the rest of the mainland .
#Text=While those ventures did n't work out so well , the urban planning that was done around this time remains .
#Text=Visitors today will see one of the few areas of Boston actually laid out on a grid .
#Text=This was also a prosperous period for locals involved in the Clipper ship industry , which flourished here .
#Text=So renowned were the shipbuilders , Eastie would remain popular in the maritime trades long after the time of wooden ships had passed .
#Text=The ships carried more than just cargo , they also brought with them new arrivals and new ideas .
#Text=A great many Canadians , Irish , Russian and European Jewish immigrants would appear throughout the 19th century .
#Text=The Italians arrived at the dawn of the 20th century , and a growing population required additional housing .
#Text=It 's during this period when the streets first became lined with ever present three deckers , providing affordable housing for the recent immigrants .
#Text=The fine Victorian mansions and sea captain 's homes would remain atop Eagle Hill , of course , along with many handsome brick bow fronts in Jeffries Point .
#Text=The construction of the airport beginning in the 1920s was transformational .
#Text=Also extremely close to downtown Boston , the noise and pollution from the air traffic kept housing prices affordable .
#Text=This provided a landing space for the most recent influx of people hailing from South and Central America , the Caribbean , and South East Asia .
#Text=Nothing stays the same forever , and today developers are moving in to capitalize on Eastie 's waterfront views and adjacency to downtown .
#Text=Get in
#Text=Clearly Logan International Airport is the neighborhood 's defining characteristic , see Boston by plane for all the gritty details .
#Text=There are , however , a few other ways to get here that do n't involve undergoing a full body patdown .
#Text=By public transit
#Text=The easiest and most popular option is the Blue line , running trains every 5-13 minutes depending on the current time and day .
#Text=It pops up above the harbor at Maverick station , before continuing on to the Airport , Wood Island , Orient Heights , and Suffolk Downs stops .
#Text=It then keeps chugging right along into Revere , the next town north .
#Text=The other way of getting here is on the Silver line SL1 branch .
#Text=It 's great for going to the airport , but not much else .
#Text=The Silver line bus makes 5 stops , one at each of Logan 's terminals , and does not connect you with the Blue line .
#Text=Busses run here ( quite a number of them ! ) , but none departing from Eastie can get you across the harbor and into Boston proper .
#Text=A few busses do leave from Wonderland station in Revere .
#Text=They drive to either Haymarket or South Station , and a couple will stop at the airport .
#Text=Of busses that do run here , the #114 , #116 , and #117 start at Maverick station and cross the Mystic river to get you into Chelsea .
#Text=The #120 and #121 run from Maverick also , but they stay within the neighborhood and in most cases the Blue line and your own two feet will be the superior option .
#Text=One other infrequently used option are the MBTA commuter boats .
#Text=Take the F2H from Logan Ferry Terminal for boats to Long Wharf , Hingham , and Hull .
#Text=These ferries run year round , but call ahead if it looks like extreme , icy ocean conditions could be an issue .
#Text=Water taxis are also available , taking you to any dock in the city with about 10 minutes notice .
#Text=By car
#Text=Driving in East Boston is n't the best idea , but not impossible .
#Text=Actually the most challenging thing is getting your car over here in the first place .
#Text=Three tunnels provide access , the older Callahan and Sumner tunnels are crowded , slow and their location is n't great .
#Text=The Ted Williams tunnel , built during the Big Dig , offers the fastest and easiest connection .
#Text=All the tunnels are equally expensive for non-resident visitors .
#Text=If you 're coming from the north , congested and crumbling routes 1A and 145 will bring you in .
#Text=There are a few parking garages , and most streets in town are resident parking only 24 hours a day .
#Text=The city issues $ 40 tickets for parking in these spaces without a sticker .
#Text=See
#Text=Belle Isle Marsh Reservation , Bennington St ( T : Suffolk Downs ) , ☏ +1617 727-5350 .
#Text=9AM-4PM daily .
#Text=This protected Saltwater Marsh is Boston 's last , and the perfect place to stroll and explore during fall , spring and summer months .
#Text=The park it self is 241 acres , and 28 of them are available to the public .
#Text=Free .
#Text=Bremen Street Community Park , Bremen St ( T : Airport ) , ☏ +1617 568-7442 .
#Text=8AM-8PM daily .
#Text=This sprawling 18-acre park in the heart of the neighborhood has bocce courts , Asian themed public gardens , playgrounds for the kids , as well as walking and bike paths .
#Text=Free .
#Text=Constitution Beach , 799 Bennington St ( T : Orient Heights ) , ☏ +1781 485-2804 x105 .
#Text=24 hours daily .
#Text=Watch the jets come in for a landing at this nice public beach .
#Text=Newly constructed bathhouse and concession stand , and there are lifeguards are on duty June to September .
#Text=Lo Presti Park , Summer and New streets ( T : Maverick ) .
#Text=Sunrise-sunset daily .
#Text=Shoot some hoops while taking in some of the best views of Boston 's downtown skyline .
#Text=The city made nearby luxury condo developers install this nicely appointed free park .
#Text=Free .
#Text=Piers Park , 95 Marginal St ( T : Maverick ) , ☏ +1617 561-6677 .
#Text=7AM-9PM daily .
#Text=7-acre beautifully landscaped waterfront park with many amenities .
#Text=Playground for the kids , fitness center , and professional sailing center renting boats and offering classes .
#Text=Great views of downtown Boston , and when its warm there are concerts and public events weekly .
#Text=Free , harbor cruise $ 85 , five-day sailing pass $ 325 .
